Award.AwardTitle: Development of Hydrophilic and Reactive QDs: Ligand Design, Surface Characterization and Effective Strategies for Coupling to Biomolecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Hedi Mattoussi of Florida State University. Prof. Mattoussi and his research group will develop luminescent quantum dot-based probes for biological applications. The project focuses on the development of a set of modular compact and multifunctional ligands for capping luminescent quantum dots (QD)-based nano-probes and the development of analytical tools to characterize them. Characterization entails determining the density of surface ligands, the number of functional groups per nanoparticle, and the development of covalently coupled QD-peptide assemblies that can be used as fluorescence resonance energy transfer substrates to evaluate the enzymatic activity of two matrix metalloproteinase proteins.

The project will provide a chemical platform to prepare stable hydrophilic luminescent quantum dots and quantum dot constructs that could be used to interrogate complex biological systems in real time. For example, quantum dot-constructs could be used to study the kinetic activity of specific enzymes and the kinetics of ligand-receptor binding. Improved understanding of enzyme kinetics and ligand-receptor binding interactions is crucial to understanding the molecular mechanism of disease development and progression and for the development of new drugs. The study will provide excellent training opportunities to students and postgraduates who seek interdisciplinary research training in synthetic chemistry and biological imaging. Prof. Mattoussi and his students will carry out extensive outreach activities to undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups at Florida A&M to broaden participation of students from underrepresented groups in nanoscience research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Some of the main outcomes of this NSF funded project include three complementary ideas:

1)      The first one centered on the development of several molecular scale hydrophilic ligands optimized for surface functionalizing luminescent quantum dots (QDs) and gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) alike.  The ligands share a common anchoring motif based on lipoic acid (LA) and hydrophilic moieties that can be made of either polyethylene glycol short chains, or zwitterion groups.  We prepared mono- and bis-(LA)-appended ligands as well as mono- and multi-PEG-modified ligands.  Similarly, we prepared zwitterion-modified mono- and bis(LA)-appended ligands. These ligands combine multi-dentate anchors, for more stable binding on the nanocrystal surfaces, and PEG or zwitterion moieties, which improve colloidal stability in biological media while reducing nonspecific interactions.  Moreover, the chemical rationale used allow easy introduction of specific reactive groups on the nanocrystal surface (e.g., COOH, amine, aldehyde, azide, …).  We have, for example, demonstrated the use of an aminoacid central scaffold (i.e., L-aspartic acid) to prepare several molecular scale LA-based ligands with varying coordination and architecture, and showed that they provide hydrophilic QDs and AuNPs with great colloidal stability. Similarly, we used the same LA and PEG motifs to prepare multicoordinating polymers and applied them for the coating of luminescent quantum dots and gold nanoparticles alike. The polymers embed a metal-specific coordinating group (e.g., dopamine for iron oxide nanoparticles, lipoic acid and/or imidazole for AuNPs and QDs.

2)      In the second we developed a new approach for ligating LA-based ligands (both molecular scale as well as polymeric) onto QDs that relies on the in-situ photochemical transformation of the lipoic acid groups under UV irradiation.  We have indeed shown that irradiation of the ligand in the presence of hydrophobic QDs using one or two phase configurations readily promotes ligand exchange and phase transfer of the QDs. Subsequently, we investigated the mechanism involved and showed that photochemical transformation of the ligands under UV irradiation can be carried out prior to ligand exchange and using simple sun light.  This photoligation route exploits the specific optical absorption feature associated with the dithiolane groups, which can produce a series of thiols and radical byproducts with enhanced reactivity towards the metal-rich surface of the QDs.  This route is milder than the one based on chemical reduction using agents such as NaBH4.  Furthermore, it preserves the integrity of functional groups that are important for use in biology, namely aldehyde and azide groups.  For example, we have combined the above chemical design with the photoligation strategy to prepare QD-capped with controllable fraction of aldehyde or azide groups using mixed ligand exchange. Furthermore, we applied the resulting aldehyde-QDs along with hydrazone ligation to extract reliable estimate of the density of ligand per nanocrystals.  We have exploited the unique and specific optical signature of the hydrazone chromophore (at 350 nm) to measure the number of CHO-appended ligand per nanocrystal. We found that the footprint area per ligand was fixed for a given ligand architecture, independent of the QD size.  Furthermore, we showed ligands presenting two LA anchoring groups produce larger foot print area, resulting in lower density on the QD surface.
